prompt.content:
One type of beetle has 3 possible wing colors, blue, green and turquoise. Randomly caught individuals of a polymorphic population were crossed with each other.
It is a monohybrid inheritance with three alleles, B, G & T. Dominance: B > G > T
You get the parent phenotype, and the distribution of phenotypes in the F1 - generation. State the genotypes of the parents and offspring as accurately as possible. No further explanation necessary. If a given distribution is impossible, state 'impossible'.
Example task:
Blue x Blue -> 4/4 Blue
Example solution:
BB x B_ -> 4/4 B_
Example Task:
Blue x Blue -> 3/4 Blue 1/4 Green
Example Solution:
BG x BG -> 1/4 BB, 1/2 BG, 1/4 GG
Blue x Gree -> 1/2 Blue 1/2 Green

It is not possible to get a 1/4 Turquoise phenotype from a Blue x Green cross, as Turquoise is a separate allele. Therefore, the solution to this example task must be one of the following:

* Blue x Green -> 1/2 Blue, 1/2 Green
* Blue x Green -> 1/2 Blue, 1/4 Green, 1/4 Turquoise

One type of beetle has 3 possible wing colors, blue, green and turquoise. Randomly caught individuals of a polymorphic population were crossed with each other.
It is a monohybrid inheritance with three alleles, B, G & T. Dominance: B > G > T
You get the parent phenotype, and the distribution of phenotypes in the F1 - generation. State the genotypes of the parents and offspring as accurately as possible. No further explanation necessary. If a given distribution is impossible, state 'impossible'.
Example task:

Example Task:

data.expected: BG x BG -> 1/4 BB, 1/2 BG, 1/4 GG
data.sampled:
The possible genotypes for a crossing between two blue beetles (BB) would be BxB and BxG. Since green beetles have one G allele and one B allele, one of the possible genotypes (BxG) would result in the F1 generation having 3/4 blue phenotypes and 1/4 green phenotypes.

The other possible genotype (GBxG) would result in all F1 offspring having green phenotypes.

prompt.content:
One type of beetle has 3 possible wing colors, blue, green and turquoise. Randomly caught individuals of a polymorphic population were crossed with each other.
It is a monohybrid inheritance with three alleles, B, G & T. Dominance: B > G > T
You get the parent phenotype, and the distribution of phenotypes in the F1 - generation. State the genotypes of the parents and offspring as accurately as possible. No further explanation necessary. If a given distribution is impossible, state 'impossible'.
Example task:
Blue x Blue -> 4/4 Blue
Example solution:
BB (Blue) x B_ (Blue) -> 4/4 B_ (Blue)
Example Task:
Blue x Blue -> 3/4 Blue 1/4 Green
Example Solution:
BG (Blue) x BG (Blue) -> 1/4 BB (Blue), 1/2 BG (Green), 1/4 GG (Green)
Blue x Turquoise -> 1/2 Blue 1/2 Turquoise

data.expected: BG (Blue) x BG (Blue) -> 1/4 BB (Blue), 1/2 BG (Blue), 1/4 GG (Green)
data.sampled:
Genotype of the parents:

Blue x Blue = Bb x Bb

Genotype of the offspring:

Bb x Bb can produce any of the following phenotypes:

* 3B (all offspring are blue)
* 2b (1/4 of the offspring are blue and 1/4 are green)
* BB (all offspring are blue)
* Bb (1/4 of the offspring are blue and 3/4 are green)

So the possible phenotypic classes in the F1 generation are:

* BB (3/4 Blue)
* 2b (not possible with these parents)
* Bb (1/4 Blue, 3/4 Green)

Therefore, the distribution is possible.

prompt.content:
One type of beetle has 3 possible wing colors, blue, green and turquoise. Randomly caught individuals of a polymorphic population were crossed with each other.
It is a monohybrid inheritance with three alleles, B, G & T. Dominance: B > G > T
You get the parent phenotype, and the distribution of phenotypes in the F1 - generation. State the genotypes of the parents and offspring as accurately as possible. No further explanation necessary. If a given distribution is impossible, state 'impossible'.
Example task:
Blue x Blue -> 4/4 Blue
Example solution:
BB (Blue) x B_ (Blue) -> 4/4 B_ (Blue)
Example Task:
Blue x Blue -> 3/4 Blue 1/4 Green
Example Solution:
BG (Blue) x BG (Blue) -> 1/4 BB (Blue), 1/2 BG (Green), 1/4 GG (Green)
Blue x Blue -> 3/4 Blue 1/4 Green

options: BG (Blue) x BG (Blue) -> 1/4 BB (Blue), 1/2 BG (Blue), 1/4 GG (Green)

data.expected: BT x BT -> 1/4 BB, 1/2 BT, 1/4 TT
data.sampled:
The genotypes of the parents are as follows:

* Parent 1: BB (homozygous for the blue allele)
* Parent 2: BG (heterozygous for the blue and green alleles)

The possible genotypes of the offspring are:

* Bb
* Bg
* Gb
* gg

Out of these, only the offspring with genotype Bb can have the phenotype blue, and the rest will have the phenotype turquoise. Therefore, the possible genotypes of the offspring are:

* Bb \* Bb = 3/4 blue
* Bb \* Bg = 1/2 blue, 1/2 turquoise
* Bg \* Bg = 1/4 blue, 3/4 turquoise
* Bg \* gg = 0 blue, all turquoise
